title: Some Vaping Patients Return to Hospitals
text:
Some patients released from the hospital after suffering from vaping-related illnesses had to be readmitted, federal health officials said Friday, suggesting the challenges of treating the mysterious lung injuries.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said it was aware of less than five hospital readmissions, but there could be more because the agency hasn’t been systematically asking.

“The issue of readmission is a relatively new consideration,” Anne Schuchat, the CDC’s principal deputy director, said on a call with reporters. “This was a particular concern to the clinical group and to the state and local public health teams.”

In the cases the agency knows about, the time between a patient’s discharge and readmission ranged from five days to 55 days.

It is unclear what prompted the patients to return. Some patients might have continued vaping and reinjured their lungs, or the original injury might have made them more susceptible to other illnesses, Dr. Schuchat said.

Some patients also had symptoms relapse after steroid treatment for their lung inflammation was tapered off following their discharges, according to the officials.

It wasn’t until this summer that doctors and public-health officials realized that patients presenting with pneumonia-like symptoms had injured their lungs due to vaping. The precise cause of the injuries is under investigation and doctors have begun exploring what, if any, long-term health effects vaping-related injuries might be.

Doctors have expressed concern that lung-scarring and difficulty breathing could linger, or long-term lung disease could crop up after the illness appeared to go away. Another concern is whether patients would be more susceptible to the flu, since weakened lungs might increase the risk of infection.

Flu season, which started this month, may also increase the difficulty of diagnosing injuries. Doctors will have to distinguish between the viral flu infection and similar symptoms in vaping patients.

““There’s going to be a lot of confusion,” Lori Shah, a transplant pulmonologist at New-York-Presbyterian and Columbia University Irving Medical Center, said.

As of Oct. 8, there have been 1,299 cases of vaping-related pulmonary illness in 49 states, the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The CDC has confirmed 26 deaths, not including a death in Utah reported on Wednesday by the Utah Department of Health. More are under investigation.

Also Friday, the CDC released guidelines to help physicians identify, treat and track patients. The agency recommended that patients should have a follow-up visit no later than one to two weeks after discharge, and should return in one to two months to potentially undergo more testing that assesses lung capacity and function.

The CDC recommends that people stop vaping THC-containing products specifically and to not buy any products from unregulated, black market sources or modify the ones they purchase legally. The majority of products linked to the illnesses contain THC, the psychoactive component in cannabis, and most were from unregulated, black market sources.

The agency also says people might want to consider refraining from nicotine vaping products, as some patients also report vaping nicotine exclusively.
description: Some patients released from the hospital after suffering from vaping-related illnesses had to be readmitted after relapses, underlining the challenges of treating the mysterious lung injuries.
